Project Description  The  Project  is  located  in  Gansu  province  in  the  poor 
northwestern region of the PRC. In 2003, the per capita gross 
domestic  product  of  Gansu  was  only  55%  of  the  national 
average. The Project will support the Government’s strategy by 
building  an  important  section  of  the  national  trunk  highway 
system connecting the two growth centers of Lanzhou, the capital 
of Gansu province, and Xi’an, the capital of Shaanxi province by 
(i) constructing an expressway across hilly to mountainous terrain 
(where the poverty incidence is high); (ii) improving local roads 
servicing  poor  counties  and  townships;  and  (iii) providing 
consulting services and training to enhance construction quality, 
road safety, and project monitoring and evaluation. 
   
Rationale  Despite considerable investment in the road sector to date, the 
PRC  road  network  is  still  inadequate,  and  does  not  provide 
efficient access to large parts of the country, particularly in the 
poorer inland regions, including Gansu province. Better transport 
links  are  necessary  to  improve  economic  efficiency,  foster 
domestic and international trade, facilitate interregional economic 
integration,  and  facilitate  efficient  economic  growth,  thereby 
reducing  poverty.  Western  PRC  lacks  high-class  road 
infrastructure. The road network must therefore be developed, 
thus spreading economic and social benefits widely. To enhance 
economic development and reduce poverty in the western region, 
the  Government  is  implementing  the  Western  Region 
Development Strategy, the key theme of the 10th Five-Year Plan  
(2001–2005).  The  strategy  aims  to  reduce  development 
disparities between the western and coastal regions. The Project 
will support this strategy. Gansu provincial  government (GPG) 
has identified the Project as a priority investment, which will also 
complement ADB’s assistance in developing the Lanzhou-Xi’an-
Taiyuan section of the national trunk highway system. 
   
Objectives  The principal objectives of the Project are to promote economic 
growth and thus reduce poverty in  eastern Gansu  province by 
lowering the cost of transport, relieving traffic congestion, and 
improving  access  in  the  project  area.  The  Project  aims  to

Risks and Assumptions  The Project was formulated to keep to a minimum the potential 
technical, safety, economic, financial, and resettlement risks. The 
main technical risks, which could result in implementation delays 
and cost overruns, are associated with  the tunnel and bridge 
structures.  To  mitigate  the  risks,  international  consultants 
reviewed  the  proposed  design  and  construction  methods. 
Prequalification  of  contractors  focuses  on  their  financial  and 
technical  capability  in  handling  complex  works.  During 
construction, monitoring and contract management information 
systems will be set up and implemented, with the assistance of 
the international consultants, for timely identification of technical 
problems and implementation of corrective measures. Given the 
safety hazards associated with bridge works, the contractors will 
be required to strictly enforce working safety rules and measures. 
GPCD  has  proven  experience  and  has  shown  satisfactory

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation (RRP) on a proposed 
loan to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Gansu Roads Development Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  The PRC’s economic growth since the 1980s has substantially increased the demand for 
transport services. The economy’s changing structure and increasing diversification have altered 
the pattern of transport demand. The demand for road transport  has outpaced that of other 
transport modes. There is a rapidly increasing  movement of goods and passengers by road, 
which is more flexible and responsive than other modes to the needs of a market economy. The 
shift in transport demand also reflects the loosening of anticompetitive restrictions in the road 
transport industry itself. Between 1990 and 2003, road traffic grew by 9.6% per annum (p.a.) for 
passenger traffic, reaching 769.6 billion passenger–kilometers (km); and by 5.7% p.a. for freight, 
reaching 708 billion ton–km. In 2003, road traffic accounted for 55.7% of the country’s total 
passenger traffic and 13.2% of the total freight traffic. With the country’s rapid economic growth, 
low vehicle ownership rates, lower automobile prices after World Trade Organization accession, 
increasing access to loans to finance automobile purchases, and large investment in automotive 
manufacturing, the rapid expansion in the vehicle fleet will continue in the coming years. 
 
3.  To meet the growing demand for mi proved transport infrastructure and services, the 
Government’s policy for the road sector, as reflected in its 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005), calls 
for (i) accelerating the construction of the network of highways and national roads, with a focus on 
five north-south and seven east-west sections of the national trunk highway system; (ii) starting 
construction of eight new highways in the western region (total 18,000 km); and (iii) by 2005, 
having approximately 1.95 million km of highways open to traffic, with expressways1 accounting 
for 35,000 km. In 2003, the Government announced plans for 5,300 rural road projects with a 
total length of 78,000 km. A total of 176,000 km of rural roads was slated for construction in the 
following 3 years, with an investment of CNY50 billion provided by the central Government. 
Currently, 184 towns and 54,000 villages, most of which are in the western region, have no 
access to roads. The plan is to develop a road network that will reach 99.8% of towns and 96.0% 
of villages by 2005. By the end of 2010, all towns and villages will be connected to roads. This 
major program will be a pro-poor initiative since in many surveys the poor ranked improved roads 
as one of their  high  infrastructure development priorities. The Government’s  commitment to 
reducing poverty through transport infrastructure investment is reflected in the poverty partnership 
agreement between the Government and ADB. The project framework  summarizing the main 
features of the proposed Project is in Appendix 1. 
 
4.  The significant road sector development during the 9th Five-Year Plan (1996–2000) 
resulted in road investments totaling CNY924 billion, or CNY185 billion per year. The road sector 
investment grew at an average annual rate of 16% during this period. During the 10th Five-Year 
Plan, the total investment is expected to reach about CNY1,800 billion, almost double that in the 
previous 5 years. A road sector  analysis is given in Appendix 2. In Gansu province, Gansu 
Provincial Communications Department (GPCD) invested about CNY4.9 billion in the road sector

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
5.  Gansu province is one of the PRC’s five northwestern provinces. Remote and isolated 
with harsh natural conditions, it is one of the least developed provinces.  The key problem in 
Gansu province is poverty: the per capita gross domestic product (GDP) of the province in 2003 
was CNY4,984, only 55% of the national average of CNY9,057.  Per capita rural income was 
CNY1,673, or 64% of the national average of CNY2,622. There are 1.6 million poor people in the 
project area, equivalent to 36% of the total population, living below the income levels of CNY900 
in rural areas and the minimum living standards in urban  areas. One of the reasons for high 
poverty incidence is slow economic growth, partly because of inadequate infrastructure. Despite 
the considerable investments, the road network is still inadequate, and does not provide efficient 
transport access to markets and social services, such as education and health.  
 
6.  The impact of road investments on poverty reduction is supported by the results of studies 
and evaluations of several completed road projects financed by ADB2 and the World Bank.3 Well-
integrated road development helps ensure that the benefits derived from the expressway filter 
down to the poor. These results affirm the relevance of ADB’s strategy in the road sector (paras. 
8–9). A technical assistance (TA)4 will help the Government formulate a road network strategy 
that promotes better integration of expressways and local roads to meet communities’ needs and 
support economic growth, and that provides road agencies with cross-disciplinary skills and tools 
through capacity building. A case study in Shaanxi  province found that improved roads were 
correlated with poverty reduction.5 Benefits for rural poor areas include lower transport costs; 
lower cost of inputs; expanded agricultural support services; improved farming practices; greater 
access to employment opportunities in urban areas; and better access to health, education, and 
social services.6

assistance has been provided mainly from ADB, Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), 
and World Bank (Appendix 4). Since 1991, ADB has provided 29 loans, totaling nearly $5.3 
billion, to finance about 3,900 km of road development, together with 7,100 km of associated local 
road networks. Since 1995, local roads have been included in the scope of road projects to make

C.  Policy Dialogue 
 
8.  Targeting Poor Beneficiaries. Since 1995, complementary local road improvement has 
been integrated into the  design of road projects to improve access to markets and social  
services.8 The integrated approach will help  target the poor in terms of bringing them benefits. 
Better integration of the local roads into the trunk highway system will help rural agricultural 
produce reach markets. As reliable transport to markets becomes more readily available, cash 
crop farming in remote areas is stimulated and the access to off-farm employment opportunities is 
broadened. 
 
9.  Five sections of the local roads of 470 km were selected as part of the broadly defined 
Project, on the basis of population density, poverty incidence, and road network efficiency from 
the Gansu Provincial Rural Road Development Plan for 2001–2010. The Project will upgrade the 
roads from Class IV to III, costing about $53 million, of which $10 million from the ADB loan will 
help finance the two road sections: Guochengyi-Houjiachuan (118 km) and Dingxi-Longxi (80 km). 
This will complement the expressway component in benefiting about 1.6 million poor people living 
in the project area. This component will  (i) be implemented concurrently with the expressway 
component and will be maintained by the county governments under the guidance of GPCD,9 
(ii) use the Ministry of Communications (MOC) technical designs and standards, (iii) follow the 
local competitive bidding procedures acceptable to ADB, and (iv) be monitored and evaluated to 
ensure that their poverty impacts are enhanced.10

(GLEC). GLEC will be responsible for operating and managing the project expressway. At least 1 
year before commencement of operations, the project expressway will be transferred to GLEC,

of traffic laws and regulations, is committed to reducing accidents  through improved safety of 
vehicles, driver training, and improved traffic management. The road traffic safety law was made

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Objectives 
 
18.  The principal objectives of the Project are to promote economic growth and reduce 
poverty in eastern Gansu province by lowering the cost of transport, relieving traffic congestion, 
and improving access in the project area. The Project aims to (i) reduce traffic accidents and 
vehicle operating costs, (ii) improve access between  Lanzhou  and  Xi’an, two major  growth 
centers in northwestern PRC, (iii) provide additional transport capacity to accommodate growing 
traffic, and (iv) provide improved access to markets and social services in poor areas. The Project 
will also support reforms relating to poverty reduction,  corporate governance, private sector 
development, and road safety and vehicle emissions.

C.  Special Features 
 
20.  Roadside Stations. Road projects have traditionally focused on expanding transport 
capacity to maximize economic impact. To contribute to achieving the Millennium Development 
Goals through transport development, innovative approaches are needed to enhance multisector 
and multipurpose dimensions of infrastructure investment. The Project will introduce roadside 
stations33 to facilitate community development along the Project local roads by linking roads with 
community activities and to provide a conducive environment for safe driving for road users. 
Roadside stations normally provide parking areas and ancillary facilities, such as bus terminals, 
gasoline stations, information centers about roads, road safety, tourism, and HIV/AIDS, local 
specialty markets, restaurants, and agro-processing facilities. Details of facilities will be firmed up 
during project implementation. The Project will develop four roadside stations along the project 
local roads. 
 
21.  Transport  Services.  To  enhance  the  benefit  flow  to  local  communities  through 
infrastructure improvement, efficient and safe transport services should be widely available in the 
project area. Current constraints and opportunities were reviewed under the TA. The main 
findings are provided in Appendix 7. One of the issues relates to the nonavailability of bus stops 
on the expressways. As the interprovincial expressway system is developed, long-distance public 
transport  services  are  becoming  available.  However,  bus  stops  are  unavailable  on  the 
expressways primarily for safety reasons, given that expressways are access controlled. MOC’s 
new highway design standards, effective 1 March 2004, provide for installing bus stops. During 
project implementation, GPCD will review the possibility of providing bus stops on the project 
expressway in consultation with bus operators, keeping in view the safety issues. Other issues 
include a lack of competition in the transport services market, and regulations on tariffs and 
routes for bus and trucking services. MOC is addressing these aspects of road transport, with 
assistance from a recently approved TA,34 which aims to develop a road transport policy reform 
action plan by reviewing the policy and regulatory framework in the road transport industry and 
factors affecting efficiency and safety of the industry.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Traffic Forecast 
 
39.  The traffic volume on the existing roads in the project area has been increasing at about 
9% per annum in the last 5 years, reaching about 3,300 vehicles per day in 2002. The roads are 
already at capacity in certain sections. If the new road is not constructed, traffic growth will be 
suppressed and transport costs will increase. The congested  traffic movements will slow the 
economic growth of the project area. Based on the findings of the TA (footnote 31), the forecast 
traffic volume on the expressway is expected to grow from 7,600 passenger car units (pcu) in 
2010 to 15,100 pcu in 2020, a 7.1% average annual growth rate. It will then grow more slowly at 
6.0% per annum thereafter to reach 25,600 pcu in 2029 (Appendix 12). 
 
B.  Economic Analysis 
 
40.  To meet the growing transport demand in the project area, possible alternatives were 
considered as part of the national and provincial transport network plan. Alternative analysis 
reviewed various options in terms of transport modes, alignments, technical designs, timing of 
investments,  and  financing  modalities.  The  conclusion  was  to  improve  road  transport  by 
constructing  an  expressway  supported  by  a  complementary  local  road  improvement.  The 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated by comparing the with- and without-project 
situations. Without the Project, the traffic volume would exceed the optimum capacity of the

14   
existing National Highway 312, which would become congested, thereby increasing travel time, 
vehicle operating costs (VOCs), and the number of accidents. With the Project, travel time will be 
reduced because of higher speeds and shorter distance; VOCs will be reduced because of faster 
and smoother travel on the expressway; and the accident rate will be reduced through the 
elimination of congestion, provision of safety features, and separation of fast- and slow-moving 
traffic. Similar benefits also accrue to the traffic on the existing road. If local roads are not 
upgraded, people in the remote parts of the project area will have less mobility and the mainly 
poor inhabitants will not be able to participate in the mainstream of economic activities. The 
economic costs of the expressway reflect the resource costs for construction, O&M, and the value 
of agricultural production from land lost permanently. The economic benefits generated by the 
expressway include (i) savings in VOCs as a result of reduced road length and improved traffic 
conditions, (ii) time savings for road users, (iii) savings from avoided physical damage as a result 
of fewer accidents, and (iv) benefits from generated traffic. 
 
41.  The EIRR for the Project is estimated at 16.6%, indicating that the Project is economically 
viable  (Appendix 13). Results of sensitivity analysis confirm the robustness of the Project's 
economic viability. Changes in the key variables, such as a 10% reduction in benefits, do not 
significantly impact on the economic viability. The capital cost would have to increase by 68% 
from the estimate for the EIRR to fall below the cutoff rate of 12%. The benefit level would have to 
decrease by 38% to achieve the same effect. In light of previous experience in the PRC road 
sector, variations of such magnitude are unlikely. The EIRR was also calculated separately for 
the expressway and for local roads. The EIRR was 16.1% for the expressway component and 
25.7% for the local road component. The economic analysis of the Project was extended to 
analyze the distribution of project net benefits by determining the project effects for various 
beneficiaries, including road users, the local economy, labor, and government. Road users will 
receive  the  largest  share  of  net  benefits,  accounting  for  79%  of  the  total  net  benefits 
(Appendix 13). 
 
C.  Financial Analysis and Projections 
 
42.  The proposed toll rates for the expressway are considered reasonable to attract sufficient 
traffic to meet economic and financial rate of return criteria. GPCD will undertake a toll analysis 
before opening the expressway, and each year for 5 years thereafter, to confirm the appropriate 
level of toll, and it will submit the results for ADB’s concurrence. If an adjustment of the toll levels 
is  required  based  on  this  principle,  GPCD  will  submit  its  toll  adjustment  plans  for  ADB’s 
concurrence before finalizing and submitting it to GPG for approval. 
 
43.  Financial projections have been prepared for GLEC in accordance with ADB's Guidelines 
for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by ADB to 
assess  the  financial  viability  and  sustainability  of  the  Project  (Appendix 14). The projected 
financial statements indicate that financial revenues will be sufficient to cover O&M costs, income 
taxes, and debt service. The financial evaluation of the expressway was undertaken in real terms 
using constant 2004 prices. Incremental costs and  revenues were derived by evaluating the 
financial  position  of  the  GLEC  under  with-  and  without-project  scenarios.  An  FIRR  for  the 
expressway, computed on an after-tax basis, is 6.1%. This compares favorably with the weighted 
average cost of capital of 2.9%. Sensitivity analysis indicates that the FIRR for the expressway is 
robust under adverse conditions. Based on the financial projections and financial evaluation of 
the  expressway  component,  the  Project  is  considered  financially  viable  and  sustainable 
(Appendix 14).

D.  Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy 
 
44.  Causes  of  poverty  in  the  project  area  include  degraded  land  and  a  lack  of  water 
resources,39  weaknesses  in  the  enabling  environment  for  the  private  sector,  and  poor 
infrastructure and access. The last point is  true especially in the rural areas due to poor  and 
seasonally accessible roads, preventing timely delivery of goods and services, and discouraging 
cash crop production, off-farm work, and labor migration, some of the main factors needed to lift 
the poor out of poverty. In urban areas, the main causes of poverty are lack of employment 
opportunities. The project area consists of areas with the potential to develop cash crops, tourism, 
and mining industries. There are 4.4 million people living in the project area: 3.9 million in the 
rural area and 0.5 million in the urban area. Of these, 1.6 million (36%) are poor, living on 
incomes below CNY900 in rural areas and the minimum living standards40 in urban areas. A 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 15 and a full poverty reduction and 
social strategy is in Supplementary Appendix F). 
 
45.  The Project design includes several measures to maximize its poverty reduction. The poor 
will use the Project local roads to sell their produce to others who will use the roads to transport 
the goods to markets. Agricultural inputs will be transported via the expressway and improved 
local roads more efficiently and cheaply to rural areas. There are many complementary poverty 
reduction activities funded by government agencies. In addition to the time and transport cost 
savings, these initiatives will improve the rural poor farmers’ terms of trade and reduce income 
poverty.  The  expressway  and  local  roads  will  facilitate  the  access  of  the  poor  to  off-farm 
employment opportunities.  The Project will create about 7,000 jobs annually during project 
implementation and about 490 jobs during operations. The nonincome dimension of poverty will 
be reduced with better access to health and education. The Project will encourage civil works 
contractors and service operators to employ the poor. 
 
46.  The incidence of HIV/AIDS in Gansu is low41 relative to other provinces. To help address 
the  issue  nationwide,  the  Action  Plan  to  Contain,  Prevent  and  Control  HIV/AIDS is being 
implemented  by  the  Ministry  of  Health  with  support  from  the  United  Nations.42 This plan 
articulates specific actions focusing on blood safety, care, and raising public awareness. In the 
context of the proposed Project, improved transport and greater population mobility due to the 
Project might lead to a short-term increase in the spread of HIV/AIDS. The Project might facilitate 
the migration of poor and seasonal workers to other provinces, whose high-risk behavior could 
spread  HIV/AIDS.  To  address  this  issue,  an  awareness-building  campaign  and  prevention 
measures are important, and some measures are being taken by the Gansu Provincial Health 
Department. Consultations with nongovernment organizations, health institutes, and transport 
operators during project preparation revealed that, while HIV/AIDS incidence is low in the project 
area, dissemination of HIV/AIDS information during construction is important and will be included

E.  Environmental Assessment 
 
48.  The Project is classified as environment category A. An EIA for the expressway was 
prepared by GPCD, and an initial environmental examination for the local roads was prepared by 
the TA consultants. A summary EIA for the Project was prepared and circulated to the Board, and 
made  public  through  ADB’s  web  site  on  30  July  2004,  based  on  the  EIA  and  the  initial 
environmental examination. To ensure that potential adverse environmental impacts of project 
design, construction, and operation are mitigated, the environmental management plan (EMP), 
containing monitoring program, mitigation measures, and acquisition of necessary permits, as 
specified in the EIA, will be implemented. Permits for individual construction work will be obtained 
prior to the works. The project highway will pass through the experimental zone of Kongtong 
Mountain  Provincial  Nature  Reserve,  where  multiple  land  uses  are  allowed.  Environmental 
impacts  on  the  reserve  areas  will  be  minimized  by  implementing  the  EMP.  Environmental 
mitigation measures will be incorporated in the civil works contracts. 
 
F.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
 
49.  The project expressway will affect 23 townships, 93 administrative villages, and 374 
village groups in  five counties—Jingchuan, Kongtong, and Jingning counties in Pingliang city, 
Huining county in Baiyin city, and Anding district in Dingxi city. Based on preliminary design data, 
1,150 ha of land will be acquired, 63% of which is farmland. The remaining land is forestland, 
housing plots, and wasteland. Approximately 100 ha of land will be occupied temporarily during 
the construction phase. The farmland acquisition involves 4,285 persons losing all their farmland. 
Investigations and past experience in Gansu reveal that each affected household loses one third 
of their farmland. Consequently, land acquisition is estimated to affect 2,840 households with 
13,150  persons.  About  55,612  square  meters  of  houses  will  be  demolished,  necessitating 
relocation of 520 households with 2,350 persons. All displaced households can be relocated a 
short distance to another site within their original village. During route selection, adjustments were 
made to minimize impacts on farmland and housing. Consequently, the adverse impact of the 
Project is relatively small and localized. Once the design for each of the road has been finished, 
GPCD will send ADB an updated resettlement plan.

G.  Risks 
 
51.  The Project was formulated to reduce potential technical, economic, financial, and social 
risks. The main technical risks are associated with the tunnel and bridge structures. To mitigate 
the risks, international consultants reviewed the proposed design and construction methods. 
Prequalification  of  contractors  focuses on their financial and technical capability in handling 
complex works. During construction, monitoring and contract management information systems 
will be set up and implemented, with the assistance of the international consultants, for timely 
identification  of  technical  problems  and  implementation  of  corrective  measures.  GPCD  has 
proven  experience  and  has  shown  satisfactory  performance  in  implementing  internationally 
financed projects. Economic performance in the project-influenced area would have to deteriorate 
substantially for the Project to lose its economic viability. The financial risks associated with 
construction and operation of the expressway will depend on the actual level and composition of 
traffic,  construction  costs,  ability  of  the  commercial  management,  and  appropriate  tolls.  To 
mitigate  the  financial  risks,  GLEC  will  build  up  a  commercial  business  environment  for 
expressway  operations,  the  project  expressway  will  receive  substantial  equity  from  the 
government, and an appropriate toll structure will be adopted. For a project that generates 
revenue in domestic currency, a risk is related to exchange rate changes, and is partly accounted 
for in the base case calculations. An adverse exchange rate change of 30% would have only a 
small effect on the financial return. 
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
 
52.  In addition to the standard assurances, the Government, GPG, and GPCD have given the 
following assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents. 
 
53.  Construction Quality. GPCD will ensure that the Project is constructed in accordance 
with 2004 technical standards of MOC for highway engineering.  The international consultant 
designated as the team leader and assistant chief supervision engineer will review and certify 
variation orders and contractors’ monthly payments, before submission to the chief supervision 
engineer. 
 
54.  Road Safety. Prior to project construction and operations, GPCD will carry out road safety 
audits, the recommendations of which will be implemented prior to project construction and 
operations.  For  the  project  expressway,  GPCD  will  implement  the  road  safety  signage, 
communication, hazard barriers, traffic monitoring, and vehicle weighing in accordance with MOC 
regulations and other regulations and standards; and will cooperate closely with the Gansu Public 
Security Bureau to implement necessary road safety measures. Before opening of the project 
expressway, GPCD in consultation with the Gansu Public Security Bureau will submit a report on 
the emergency response plan to ADB for review.

55.  Roadside Stations and Transport Services. Prior to completion of the local roads under 
the Project, GPCD will establish four roadside stations to facilitate community development by 
linking such roads with community activities. Facilities to be provided at the roadside stations may 
include parking areas; bus terminals; gasoline stations; information centers about roads, road 
safety, tourism and HIV/AIDS; local specialty markets; restaurants; and agro-processing facilities. 
These will be reviewed by GPCD by the time of the midterm review. GPCD will also review by 
then the possibility of providing bus stops along the project expressway, in consultation with bus 
operators, with due regard for safety. 
 
56.  Corporatization. By 31 December 2007, GPCD will establish a company, tentatively 
called the Gansu Luoding Expressway Company (GLEC), to operate and manage the proposed 
project expressway. At least 1 year before start of operations, the project expressway will be 
transferred to GLEC. Details on the creation of GLEC and transfer of assets and debt service 
obligations from GPCD to GLEC, including GLEC’s financial statements for the Project, will be 
submitted for ADB approval 6 months prior to the establishment of GLEC. GLEC will implement a 
corporate  development  plan  by  31  December  2008  to  assure  high  standards  of  corporate 
governance, management practices, and financial reporting. The concept of an interprovincial 
expressway corporation will be reviewed by GPCD prior to project completion. 
 
57.  Private Sector Development. By 30 June 2008,  GPCD will enter into a concession 
framework  agreement  with  GLEC  to  ensure  autonomy  of  operations,  encourage  the 
establishment of road performance indicators, and facilitate future refinancing of road sector 
assets. Six months before the opening of the project facilities, GPCD will analyze the feasibility of 
attracting private sector investment funds for future road sector investment, including private 
sector participation in O&M of the project expressway, and report its conclusions to ADB. 
 
58.  Tolls. In determining toll level, GPG will take into consideration levels sufficient to satisfy 
GLEC’s debt service coverage ratio of a minimum of 1.2. Six months before the expressway is 
opened, GPCD will seek ADB’s concurrence on the proposed toll structure and levels prior to 
seeking GPG approval. For the first 5 years of operation, GPCD will review the toll structure and 
levels annually, and submit a report to ADB. GPCD will seek ADB’s concurrence on toll level 
adjustment before seeking GPG approval. 
 
59.  Financial Ratios. To ensure financial sustainability, GPCD will cause GLEC to maintain 
(i) a debt-to-equity ratio of not more than 65:35 from the third year of operation; (ii) a working ratio 
(annual O&M cost, but excluding periodic maintenance cost, to revenue) of not more than 15%; 
and (iii) a debt service coverage ratio of not less than 1.2 from the third year of operation. 
 
60.  Human Resource Development and Training. GPCD will prepare a human resource 
development plan. Before undertaking international training, GPCD will prepare, among others for 
ADB’s concurrence, a training plan, a program of workshops to be delivered at GPCD by those 
trained internationally, and a list of training equipment and aids to strengthen GPCD’s domestic 
training programs.  
 
61.  Environment. GPCD will ensure that the Project is designed, constructed, and operated 
in accordance with government rules and regulations and ADB’s Environmental Policy (2002). 
GPCD will implement the EMP set out in the EIA and summary EIA to mitigate any adverse 
environmental impacts arising from the Project; mitigation measures will be incorporated in the 
bidding documents and civil works contracts. GPG will re-demarcate the boundary of nature 
reserve appropriately in accordance with government regulations and procedures.

penalties for infringement of such standards, and (ii) ensure that Gansu Environmental Protection 
Bureau (GEPB), Gansu Public Security Bureau, and other relevant agencies enforce the national 
vehicle emission standards, and fulfill requirements of the government strategies, at least 6 
months prior to the opening of the expressway. 
 
63.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement. GPG and GPCD will ensure that land acquisition 
and resettlement are carried out promptly and efficiently following the resettlement plan agreed 
with  ADB,  in  line  with  the  Land  Administration  Law  and  ADB's  Policies  on  Involuntary 
Resettlement  (1995)  and  Indigenous  Peoples  (1998).  GPG  and  GPCD  will  ensure  that 
implementation of the resettlement plan is monitored and evaluated and reported to ADB as 
required in the plan. 
 
64.  Ethnic Minorities. GPCD will implement the SDAP to ensure that ethnic minorities benefit 
from the Project in at least an equitable manner and in accordance with ADB's Policy on 
Indigenous  Peoples  (1998),  and  that  implementation  of  the  SDAP  will  be  monitored  and 
evaluated by an independent agency. 
 
65.  Poverty Reduction. The Government will cause GPG to implement the SDAP in a timely 
manner. GPCD will cause the contractors to maximize the employment of local poor people who 
meet the job and efficiency requirements for construction of the project roads. Such workers will 
be provided with on-the-job training. The Government will cause GPG to extend the coverage and 
quality of public utilities, basic health, and basic education in the project area to enhance the 
Project’s poverty reduction impacts. The Poverty Alleviation Office, in consultation with GPCD, 
will monitor the impacts on poverty with the assistance of a designated local institute based on a 
set of indicators as outlined in the SDAP, and will submit annual monitoring reports to ADB. 
 
66.  Labor  Standards.  GPCD  will  ensure  that  civil  works  contractors  comply  with  all 
applicable labor legislation. Bidding documents will include a clause on the prohibition of child 
labor for construction and maintenance activities, as well as a clause ensuring equal pay for men 
and women for work of equal value. 
 
67.  Gender and Development. GPCD will follow ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
(1998) during project implementation, and will take all necessary actions to encourage women to 
participate in planning and implementing the Project. GPCD will monitor the effects on women 
during  project  implementation  through  gender-disaggregated  data  where  relevant  in  the 
resettlement plan and the monitoring and evaluation system. 
 
68.  Health  Risks.  The  Department  of  Health  and  GPCD,  together  with  the  appropriate 
authorities, will ensure that contractors disseminate information on the risks of HIV/AIDS to those 
employed during project implementation. The Department of Health and GPCD will also ensure 
that similar information is disseminated to transport operators and local communities living in the 
project area during project operation, at roadside stations and other suitable facilities. 
 
69.  Axle Loads. GPCD will install vehicle axle-weighing equipment at selected entry points. 
Before opening the project expressway, GPCD will submit to ADB the plan for operation of the 
vehicle weigh stations, including the prescribed axle-load limits and penalties for infringement. 
 
70.  Change in Ownership. If (i) any change in ownership of the project facilities, or (ii) any 
sale, transfer, or assignment of GPCD’s interest in the project expressway is anticipated, the 
Government, GPG, and GPCD will consult ADB at least 6 months before the change.

ROAD SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Road Network 
 
1.  The People’s Republic of China’s (PRC’s) road network was 1.81 million kilometers (km) 
in 2003, an increase of 44,600 km from 2002. Of this, 1.44 million km were classified. Class II 
and above roads accounted for 271,600 km, 15% of  the total length.  The road density has 
increased from 12.1 km per 100 square km (km2) in 1995 to 18.9 km per 100 km2 in 2003. That 
year,  Gansu’s  road  network  accounted  for  2.2%  of  the  country’s  total,  with  a  length  of 
40,224 km. Of this total, 30,806 km (76.6 %) were classified: 319 km of expressways (0.8%), 
154 km of Class I roads (0.4%), 4,134 km of Class II roads (10.3%), and 26,199 km of Class III–
IV roads (65.1%). Unclassified roads amounted to 9,418 km (23.4%). The road density in Gansu 
was 8.9 km per 100 km2, significantly lower than the national average. 
 
2.  The  United  Nations  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific  is 
promoting a trans-regional Asian Highway Network, extending 140,000 km, of which 26,000 km 
are in the PRC. Road projects funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) are contributing to 
the development of this network through a total of 13 completed or planned projects comprising 
2,100 km, with a total loan amount of about $2.4 billion. 
  
B.  Vehicle Fleet and Traffic 
 
3.  In 2003, the PRC vehicle fleet totaled 24 million trucks, cars, and buses, and 72 million 
other motorized vehicles (motorcycles and agricultural vehicles). The privately owned fleet of 
motor vehicles increased more than 20 times during 1985–2003, from 0.3 million vehicles to 
12 million. Despite the rapid increase in total vehicles, there are only about 1.3 vehicles for 100 
persons, which is low relative to other Asian countries. The PRC’s accession to the World Trade 
Organization  has  increased  investment  in  the  automobile  industry,  reduced  the  tariffs  on 
imported vehicles, and contributed to making motor vehicle financing easier to access. These 
factors,  plus  rapidly  growing  urban  incomes,  underpin  the  growth  in  road  traffic.  The 
modernization of the vehicle fleet will improve vehicle safety and reduce individual vehicles’ fuel 
consumption and their emissions. In 2003, the number of vehicles registered in  Gansu was 
134,900 passenger vehicles and 116,600 freight vehicles. Vehicle ownership in Gansu is lower 
than the national average. Privately owned vehicles totaled 100,000. Road passenger traffic in 
Gansu province measured in terms of passenger-km of travel grew by more than 70% between 
1990 and 2002, reaching 134 million. Road freight traffic, in ton-km, grew by 43% during the 
same period. 
 
C.  Road Administration 
 
4.  Gansu Provincial Communications Department (GPCD) is responsible for regulating the 
road transport industry in  Gansu by licensing drivers, vehicles, and intercity bus services. 
Freight transport is essentially deregulated; however, interprovincial bus routes require Ministry 
of Communications (MOC) approval. Through trucking reforms, there has been an increase in 
private  operations  resulting  in  improved  transport  efficiency  and  quality  of  services  and 
increased competition.  ADB is supporting this process through  a technical assistance (TA),1 
which aims to help improve the performance of the road transport industry by formulating policy 
reforms in the road freight and passenger services. Road administration is decentralized. Road

D.  Road Sector Revenue and Expenditures 
 
5.  Expenditures  in  highway  infrastructure  are  financed  from  dedicated  user  charges, 
government grants, domestic bank loans and bonds, and foreign loans and investments. Two 
dedicated user charges, the road maintenance fee and vehicle purchase fee, have provided 
much of the financing for the road sector. During the Ninth Five-Year Plan of 1996–2000, the 
road maintenance fee and vehicle purchase fee provided 53% and 13%, respectively, of the 
total road investments. Government grants provided 2% mainly to construct or improve rural 
roads in poor areas. The rest was financed from domestic loans and bonds (9%), other 
domestic investments including financing from local governments and state-owned enterprises 
(12%), foreign loans (8%), and foreign direct investment (3%). 
 
6.  As  part  of  a  tax  reform  to  bring  off-budget  revenue  and  expenditures  within  the 
framework of the national budget, the National People’s Congress passed amendments to the 
Highway Law on 31 October 1999. The amendments laid the foundation for future legislation 
providing for national taxes to replace provincial and local fees. The vehicle purchase fee was 
replaced by the vehicle purchase tax effective January 2001, and a fuel tax is being considered 
to replace the road maintenance fee. Based on findings of an ADB-financed TA,2 the fuel tax is 
likely to improve financing of the road sector.  
 
7.  In Gansu province, GPCD invested about CNY4.9 billion in the road sector in 2003, of 
which 65% was allocated to construction and 9% to maintenance. During the 10th Five-Year 
Plan (2001–2005), total investment is expected to be about CNY24 billion with an annual 
average growth rate of 5.8% during this period. GPCD plans to nearly double road investment to 
CNY44 billion during the 11th Five-Year Plan. 
 
E.  Road Engineering, Construction, and Maintenance 
 
8.  Road  projects  are  designed  by  planning  and  design  institutes  at  the  provincial, 
prefecture, and county levels. MOC reviews the designs of expressways, high-standard roads, 
and  associated  structures.  Design  institutes  are  staffed  with  experienced,  well-qualified 
personnel. The city and county highway bureaus have their own construction units to carry out 
minor projects within their administrative districts. Drawing on the experience gained under 
ADB- and World Bank-financed projects, competitive bidding practices were mandated by the 
1999 Tendering and Bidding Law.3 Many of the largest provincial and urban construction units 
are being reorganized into financially independent companies and have been awarded contracts 
individually or as partners in joint ventures on several ADB- and World Bank-financed in-country 
or overseas projects. 
 
9.  Road maintenance is well organized by the expressway companies and the highway 
administration bureaus and is carried out mainly through labor-intensive operations but with 
increasing  amounts  of  mechanized  works.  Although  maintenance  expenditures  increased 
significantly in absolute terms in the past decade and maintenance is generally adequate,

F.  Government’s Rural Road Development Program 
 
10.  MOC has prepared a National Rural Road Development Plan. Under this plan, rural 
roads  will  be  developed  in  three  stages.  By  2005,  the  length  of  rural  roads  will  total 
1.55 million km; by 2010, 1.85 million km, connecting all townships and administrative villages in 
the  country;  and  by  2020,  2.5 million km,  and  transport  services  will  be  provided  to 
administrative village level. 
 
G.  Road Transport Services 
 
11.  A relaxation of trucking regulations in the 1980s allowed privately owned trucks to haul 
cargo for state-owned factories and cooperatives. Privately owned trucks expanded their market 
share during the 1990s at the expense of state-owned transport companies, many of which are 
now being privatized. The competition improves road transport efficiency and service quality. 
MOC is encouraging the private sector to augment the overall capacity of the road transport 
industry.  In  the  future  more  small  freight  operators  will  merge  and  there  will  be  more 
privatization of large state-owned companies. 
 
12.  To enhance benefits flowing to local communities through infrastructure improvement, it 
will be necessary to ensure that efficient and safe transport services are in place. One of the 
issues relates to the lack of bus stops on the expressways. As the interprovincial expressway 
system is developed, long-distance public transport services are becoming available for the 
people living along the expressways. However, bus stops are unavailable on the expressways 
primarily for safety reasons, given that the expressways are access controlled. MOC’s new 
highway design standards, effective 1 March 2004, provide for installing bus stops either along 
the main lanes or at the service areas. GPCD will review the possibility of providing bus stops 
on the project expressway in consultation with bus operators during project implementation, 
keeping in view of the need to address safety aspects. Other issues are lack of competition in 
the transport services market; regulations on tariff and routes for bus and trucking services; and 
insufficient credit for purchasing vehicles, especially for rural and informal vehicles. These 
aspects of road transport are being addressed by MOC and selected provinces with assistance 
provided under a recently approved TA.5

ROAD SAFETY AND VEHICLE EMISSIONS 
 
A.  Road Safety 
 
1.  The  Traffic  Management  Department  of  Gansu  Public  Security  Bureau  (GPSB)  is 
responsible for recording and managing accident data for Gansu province. About 84% of all 
accidents  were  caused  by  driver  error,  with  26%  involving  unlicensed  drivers.  Weather 
conditions did not have a large impact on the number of accidents (79% of accidents occur 
during fine weather and 9% during cloudy weather). There were more accidents in the day than 
at night (75% of all accidents were during the day). There was no relationship between road 
conditions and accident rates as 82% of accidents occurred on normal road sections, with 73% 
of these accidents taking place on straight, flat roads. The majority of accidents occur on city 
trunk roads and lower grade (Class II or III) roads. Lack of proper driver training, inadequate 
enforcement of traffic regulations, alcohol, and the lack of use of seat belts and infant car seats 
contribute to the high accident and death rates. 
 
2.  The cause of most traffic accidents in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) seems to be 
a neglect of traffic rules and people’s casual attitude toward road safety. Given this situation, the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) supported the development of a comprehensive action plan in 
2001 to address critical road safety issues in the PRC. This resulted in the revision of traffic 
laws that became effective on 1 May 2004 with the goal of reducing traffic accidents. There has 
also been a radio publicity campaign to promote driver awareness. 
 
3.  Every year, the Traffic Management Department prepares a road safety action plan 
based on the results of analyses of traffic accidents from the previous year. Some strategies to 
reduce traffic accidents are as follows:  
 
(i)  establishing an Accident Protection Division and setting up branch organizations 
in counties and villages. The work of branch units is carried out with local traffic 
police and other relevant organizations. GPSB analyzes accident data collected 
from each organization to draw up future strategies;  
(ii)  strengthening police checks and increasing police patrols on roads to enforce 
traffic laws and regulations; and 
(iii)  promoting  traffic  safety  via  pamphlets,  posters,  and  other  modes  of 
communications  that  promote  the  use  of  seat  belts  and  cover  the  adverse 
relationship between road safety and alcohol consumption. 
 
4.  Accident-prone areas are selected and targeted by GPSB yearly. Measures to eliminate 
them  include:  (i) educating  drivers  about  safe  driving  and  dangerous  road  conditions; 
(ii) locating police checkpoints at or near black spots; (iii) installing speed limits and other 
warning signs and plates in easy-to-see locations; (iv) installing guardrails, traffic barriers, or 
fences at curves; (v) changing traffic lane markings when necessary from white to yellow  in 
color; and (vi) improving the cross grade at sharp curves. 
 
5.  Most accidents are caused by driver error due to speeding, overloading, neglecting 
traffic signals, dangerous overtaking, or consumption of alcohol. Accidents caused by faulty 
road structure are small in number and are sometimes due to poor pavement conditions as a 
result of insufficient maintenance. The structure of the proposed expressway, which is based on 
PRC’s Highway Design Standards presents no problems in terms of road safety.

6.  While horizontal and vertical alignments meet safety standards, there is still room for 
improvement. Safety facilities will be reinforced for the alignment near Pingjiashan Tunnel. For 
example, a special lane marking consisting of continuous broken lines on either side is effective 
at sharp curves for visually informing drivers of a potentially dangerous upcoming section of

7.  Road safety facilities and equipment for expressway operations can be divided into three 
types according to their function. The first type directly affects driver behavior, the second type 
is for responding to accidents, and the third type is for accident prevention. Examples of such

affecting driver behavior, including (a) crash barriers, (b) special lane marking, (c) variable traffic 
information  boards,  and  (d)  traffic  monitoring  systems;  (ii) accident  response,  including 
(a) emergency telephones, (b) station post signs, (c) vehicles and tools required for accident 
attendance or investigation; and (iii) accident prevention, including (a) speed measurement 
devices, (b) devices for measuring the amount of alcohol consumed by drivers, (c) axle load 
measurement devices, and (d) accident data recording and analysis system.  
 
B.  Vehicle Emissions 
 
8.  Vehicle ownership in the PRC has been increasing sharply, with much of this growth 
occurring in cities. Nationally, the annual growth of vehicles has averaged 14% per year. The 
total number of motorized vehicles reached 96.5 million by the end of 2003, 21% higher than in 
2002. One result of this rapid growth has been the emergence of motor vehicle air pollution 
problems, especially in cities. The growth in the vehicle fleet will continue in coming decades, 
resulting in concerns regarding further environmental degradation. It is estimated that vehicle 
emissions will account for 79% of air pollution by 2005. 
 
9.  Key  environment-related  motor  vehicle  programs  include  those  in  the  areas  of 
(i) national  emissions  standards  for  new  vehicles,  (ii) improvement  of  conventional  fuels, 
(iii) alternative  or  cleaner  fuels,  (iv) vehicle  inspection  and  maintenance  programs,  and 
(v) retirement of obsolete polluting vehicles. 
 
10.  The government emission standards for new vehicles are as follow: (i) the limits and 
measurement methods for exhaust pollutants from compression ignition engines of vehicles, 
issued on 16 April 2001, has been implemented in two stages: (a) from 16 April 2001 to 1 
September 2003, and (b) from 1 September 2003; (ii) limits and measurement methods for 
exhaust pollutants from positive ignition engines of vehicles and vehicles equipped with positive 
ignition engines, issued on 27 November 2002, has been implemented in two stages: (a) from 1 
January  2003  to  1  September  2003;  and  (b) from  1  September  2003;  (iii) limits  and 
measurement methods for exhaust emissions from motorcycles under running mode, issued on 
27 November 2002, have been implemented in three stages: (a) from 1 January 2003, (b) from 
1 July 2003 to 31 December 2004, and (c) from 1 January 2005; (iv) limits and measurement 
methods for exhaust emissions from motorcycles at idle speed, issued on 18 November 2002, 
have been implemented in two stages: (a) from 1 January 2003, and (b) from 1 July 2003; 
(v) limits and measurement methods for exhaust emissions from mopeds under running mode, 
issued on 27 November 2002, have been implemented in two stages: (a) from 1 January 2003 
and (b) from 1 January 2004. 
 
11.  These standards are approximately equivalent to the Euro II performance standards. 
Vehicles failing to meet the standards cannot be manufactured, imported, sold, or registered.

12.  Measures have been taken to phase out the distribution of leaded fuels. Since 1 January 
2000 there has been no further production, and since 1 July 2000, no sales of leaded fuels have 
been permitted in the PRC. Trucks and heavy vehicles mostly use diesel engines that do not 
require any lead additives. There has been no difficulty in switching to unleaded fuel as it 
became available. Leaded gasoline is no longer available in urban areas, although old stocks of 
leaded gasoline in some rural areas may still be sold.  
 
13.  Sulfur content is regulated via petroleum-refining production standards (content- and 
quality-based). The limitation for sulfur content in the standards of unleaded gasoline for motor 
vehicles and the hazardous materials control standard for motor vehicle gasoline is less than 
0.08% (m/m). The Government has targeted sulfur in fuels as part of broader sulfur dioxide 
control efforts. 
 
14.  To  reduce  vehicle  emissions,  the  Government  has  established  the  National  Clean 
Automobile Working Team led by the Ministry of Science and Technology, which is committed 
to speeding up the development and use of clean fuel vehicles. A pilot program for the utilization 
of clean fuel has been implemented in 12 cities, including Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, and 
Chongqing.  The  PRC’s  four  leading  vehicle  makers  have  been  designated  as  production 
centers for natural gas-powered vehicles. By October 2003, the number of natural gas-powered 
vehicles reached 190,000 and 560 gas stations had been built in 16 major cities to support the 
move.

TRANSPORT SERVICES IN THE PROJECT AREA 
 
1.  Village-Based  Transport. Within  the  30  villages  surveyed  by  the  TA  consultants, 
motorized tricycles (45%) and motorcycles (38%) are the most common vehicles followed by 
utility vehicles (11%), trucks (2.5–5 ton) (4%), and minivans (2%). Vehicles are an important 
source of income for most owners. Almost every household has at least one bicycle, but during 
winter the poor road conditions and the weather prevent their use. Motorized tricycles are the 
most common method of transporting goods and agricultural produce to markets as well as from 
farmlands to houses, and occasionally passengers. These are relatively less expensive vehicles 
costing  in  a  range  of  CNY2,000–CNY20,000  in  the  project  area  depending  on  the  type. 
Upgrading local roads will contribute to lower maintenance costs and greater safety of tricycles.  
 
2.  Bus Services. The quality of bus services varies from place to place. Most villages are 
located along a road where regular bus services are available. Within the villages surveyed, 
most people are satisfied with the level of bus services available. People use bus services to 
(i) go shopping, (ii) visit a doctor or hospital, (iii) attend middle school, (iv) travel for employment 
purposes,  (v) carry  out  trade  activities,  and  (vi) visit  family  or  friends.  The  villages  were 
surveyed for frequency of bus services; 52% had 5–10 buses per day; 22% had 11–30 buses 
per day; 11% had more than 30 buses per day; and 15% had less than 5 buses per day. Those 
villages with the best access are those located along National Highway 312. Other villages are 
less well served. The quality of the bus services ranges from moderate to good.  
 
3.  Freight  Companies.  Of  the  three  freight  companies  interviewed,  two  companies 
transport  mainly  consumer  durables,  dry  foods,  construction  materials,  and  coal.  Of  the 
products shipped out of the province by one company, 70% is agricultural produce. Attitudes to 
toll roads vary. One company believes that tolls have little impact on freight charges, another 
that the total freight cost is reduced due to better road conditions, and the third that the 
additional cost is equally shared between the company and the customer. All three companies 
noted that rural poor roads result in higher oil consumption and vehicle wear and tear, which 
undermine profits. Rates charged are based on various criteria depending on each company, 
such as (i) weight of goods, (ii) an  underloaded  truck counted as a full load, (iii) tons per 
kilometer, and (iv) higher rates for transporting fresh produce. 
 
4.  Manufacturers also use freight companies.  Five manufacturers operating in Lanzhou 
city, Pingliang city, and three in the project area counties were interviewed. All used the existing 
highway, the benefits being (i) shorter driving time, (ii) reduction of wear and tear on vehicles 
leading to lower maintenance costs, (iii) little damage to goods, and (iv) safety. Transport costs 
as a share of the price of goods ranges from 10% to 40%. All respondents agreed that the road 
quality affects the efficiency of their business and that narrow roads of poor quality seriously 
affect driving speeds and cause congestion, which damages or delays delivery of goods, 
jeopardizes the company’s image, and reduces profits. 
 
5.  Wholesalers. Agricultural wholesalers collect produce from villagers as shown in Table 
A7. Most of the produce handled by these wholesalers is shipped outside the county or 
province. The maximum proportion sold within the county is 25%. All those interviewed used toll 
roads due to (i) smooth traffic flow and consistent speed with few obstacles, no poor or rugged 
sections, and no need to drive through population centers; and (ii) savings on time, vehicle 
operation and maintenance costs, and fuel costs. Disadvantages include (i) traffic congestion 
due to a limited number of opened toll gates or a long time taken for police vehicle inspection at 
the toll gates, and (ii) high tolls.

TRAFFIC FORECAST 
 
1.  Traffic surveys were made initially in May and June 2000 in and around the area of 
National Highway (NH) 312 under the feasibility study for the Project. Based on these surveys, a 
traffic  demand  model  was  constructed  and  traffic  forecasts  carried  out  and  subsequently 
updated in 2002. The model was refined under the technical assistance (TA) by carrying out 
additional surveys consisting of rail and bus user interviews and traffic counts. Based on the 
work of the TA team, the traffic forecasts for the Project, which focused on the Lanzhou-Xi’an 
transport corridor, have been finalized and are described below. 
 
2.  The road network that extends from Lanzhou to Xi’an has four existing routes, consisting 
of national highways and a provincial highway (PH) and are as follows: (i) NH312, (ii) NH309, 
(iii) NH310-NH316-PH209, and (iv) NH310-NH045. The traffic volume for the existing NH312 
increased during 1995–2000 at 8.6% per annum. Then there was a drop in 2001 due to the 
opening of an alternative road between Chankou and Tianshui. Traffic volume started to make a 
strong recovery in 2002. 
 
3.  Analysis of future traffic demand took into account four modes of road travel: passenger 
vehicles, buses, trucks, and large trucks. The technique applied to forecasting future traffic 
demand is the four-step estimation method and predicts traffic in a four-step process that covers 
trip generation/attraction, trip distribution, modal split, and traffic assignment. The forecast years 
for the Project are 2010, 2015, 2020, and 2029. 
 
4.  Trip Generation.  Trip  generation  and  attraction  models  were  constructed  for  nine 
internal zones to cover the 10 counties of the project area that lie on either side of NH312, while 
growth rate factors were applied to derive the generated and attracted trips for 16 external 
zones. The generation and attraction models were constructed after examining and applying 
such socioeconomic factors as gross domestic product (GDP), GDP per capita, population, and 
vehicle ownership. Based on these models, it was possible to derive total trips for each of the 
target years.  
 
5.  Trip Distribution. Trip distribution was carried out using the total trips generated/ 
attracted for each of the target years and applied to the updated origin-destination (OD) 
matrixes in order to make direct use of observed traffic flows. The validity of these matrixes was 
first confirmed by comparing actual link flows with flows obtained from the assignment of the OD 
matrixes for the base year.  
 
6.  Modal Split. Modal split for rail- and road-based modes was carried out based on the 
following principles: (i) a modal split model using an exponential function as a diversion curve 
with time as a variable was applied to forecast the shifting of passengers between rail and bus; 
(ii) based on survey data, it was assumed that there would be virtually no shifting between bus 
and private passenger cars, given that only 1% of bus users own a car; (iii) it was assumed that 
there would be a shift of about 8% of rail passengers to private passenger vehicles based on 
survey data; and (iv) in the case of cargo diversion, it was assumed that a shift in non-bulk high-
value cargo, which accounts for only about 5% of total rail cargo, would occur as a result of the 
construction of the project expressway. 
 
7.  Assignment. Based on the updating and validation of the OD matrixes of the feasibility 
study and then the future prediction of trips via the construction of the above models, future 
interzonal trips for each of the target years were assigned to the road network of the corridor 
using an incremental traffic assignment model. This model operates on the principle of equal

slowdown of travel time on that route, and part of the traffic then diverts to another route with a

available, or until the point of equal travel times is reached. Of the trips that use the project

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
1.  The project expressway1 traverses the eastern part of Gansu province. Local roads are 
connected to the expressway through the road network system. The economic analysis covers 
the 25 years of construction and operation. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of the 
project expressway was estimated by comparing the situation with and without the Project. 
Without the Project, traffic will use the existing road network, which will be congested and 
expensive to maintain due to the rapidly increasing volume of traffic. Some travel may not take 
place because of the congestion and the resulting increasing travel times and vehicle operating 
costs (VOCs). With the Project, congestion on the existing roads will be reduced, and traffic on 
the expressway and the existing roads will benefit from faster, cheaper, and safer travel. Some 
additional trips will be generated as the economy responds to lower transport costs and better 
service. 
 
2.  Alternative Analysis. Possible alternative interventions were considered to meet the 
growing transport demand in the project area as part of the national and provincial transport 
network  plan.  Alternative  analysis  reviewed  various  options  in  terms  of  transport  modes, 
alignments, technical designs, timing of investments, and financing modalities. While enhancing 
the existing railway capacity may be an option to partly meet the increasing demand, it will not 
completely satisfy the various kinds of traffic, particularly high-value general cargo that requires 
a more flexible and responsive mode to meet the needs of a market economy. Six alternative 
alignments  were  reviewed  based  on  geologic  and  topographical  conditions,  terrain 
considerations, consultations with community representatives, cost estimates, relative impacts 
on environment and resettlement, and integration with the national and local transport network. 
The expressway technical design was proposed after consideration of the national highway 
network,  consistency  in  the  standards  of  contiguous  sections  at  each  end  of  the  project 
expressway, and forecast traffic. Alternative financing modalities were considered, including 
private sector investment. However, private sector investment was not found attractive due to 
risks associated with construction and low estimated rates of return. Hence public financing was 
considered appropriate. 
 
3.  Expressway Component. The economic evaluation was undertaken using constant 
2004 prices. The project costs and benefits were revalued at economic prices by separating the 
cost items into tradable materials and equipment and nontradable materials, labor, and land. 
The  prices  were  expressed  in  yuan  using  the  domestic  price  numeraire  with  a  shadow 
exchange rate factor of 1.01 for foreign exchange effects. A shadow price was used to put an 
economic value on the wages paid to unskilled labor, but not on wages for skilled labor since 
there was no surplus of skilled workers. A shadow wage rate factor of 0.5 was used to convert 
the financial wage rate to an economic opportunity cost of labor. The costs of the expressway 
include:  (i) the  capital  costs,  including  physical  contingencies,  land  acquisition,  and 
resettlement; and (ii) the costs of operating and maintaining the expressway. The land and 
resettlement costs were based on their opportunity costs, i.e., agricultural output forgone and re-
siting of displaced activities. 
 
4.  The economic benefits include (i) savings in VOCs resulting from the reduced  travel 
distance and improved road conditions, (ii) savings in the value of passenger time and of freight

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN  
 
1.  The  resettlement  plan  covers  the  construction  of  an  expressway  between 
Luohandong and Dingxi, related connecting roads, and complementary local roads. The Gansu 
provincial government has assured the Asian Development Bank (ADB) that the affected people 
for the local roads will receive the same compensation and other assistance provided in the 
resettlement plan. The Gansu Provincial Communication Department (GPCD) is the Executing 
Agency. Once the detailed measurement survey is completed, the resettlement plan will be 
updated, distributed to affected people, and submitted to ADB for concurrence. 
 
2.  The project expressway will affect 23 townships, 93 administrative villages, and 374 
village groups in five counties (Jingchuan county, Kongtong district, and Jingning county in 
Pingliang municipality, Huining county in Baiyin municipality, and Anding district in  Dingxi 
municipality). About 1,150 hectares (ha) of land will be acquired, 63% of which are farmland, 
comprising paddy (16%) and dryland (47%), and 100 ha of land will be occupied temporarily. 
Based on per capita farmland in the affected villages, the farmland acquisition is equivalent to 
4,285 persons losing all of their farmland. Most people will in fact only lose part of their 
farmland. For this project, it is estimated that the average loss is one-third, which means land 
acquisition will directly affect about 13,150 persons. About 55,612 square meters (m2) of houses 
will be demolished, necessitating relocation of 520 households (2,350 persons). Most of these 
households will be moved a short distance to another site within their original village. All land, 
housing, and other assets will be compensated at replacement value. The local road component 
may also involve land acquisition, which will be reported in the updated resettlement plan. Due 
diligence was carried out for the Ningxia section, linking two parts of the project expressway. 
The report on the due diligence is annexed to the resettlement plan. 
 
3.  The resettlement objective is to achieve equal or better income and living standards 
in line with the PRC Land Administration Law (1998) and the ADB’s policy on involuntary 
resettlement. GPCD will ensure that people losing land, housing, other assets, or income source 
will be helped to fully restore their income and living standards. The land compensation rate will 
be CNY12,000/mu for irrigated farmland; CNY6,000/mu for dry land and housing plots; and 
CNY1,900/mu for forest land. For demolished structures, the replacement value will be provided 
to  the  affected  households  based  on  compensation  rates,  which  range  from  CNY350–
CNY460/m2 for brick-concrete structures, CNY200–CNY300/m2 for brick-wood structures, and 
CNY200/m2 for earth-wood structures. Households will be provided funds to purchase a new 
housing  site  serviced  with  road,  electricity,  and  water  within  the  current  village  group  or 
administrative village. There will be no reduction in compensation for depreciation and people 
will be allowed to salvage materials from their old houses. Seventeen urban households will be 
relocated and the compensation rate is in the range of CNY630–CNY830/m2. GPCD will ensure 
that compensation provided will be sufficient to purchase replacement housing.

compensation funds collectively to improve farm conditions, develop cash crops, and finance 
various nonfarm activities. New employment and income generation opportunities will arise 
once the expressway and local roads are constructed.
